question: A traffic light is red $ 40\%$ of the times you drive through an intersection. If you follow that route twice, find the probability of obtaining two red lights.

How many solutions does the following linear system has?
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & 2y & = & 4 \\
x & - & 2y & = & 0 \\
4x & + & 3y & = & 12
\end{cases}$$
answer2: The system has $\left(2,\,1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has $\left(\frac{24}{11},\,\frac{12}{11}\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has an infinite number of solutions of the form $\left(2y,\,y\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:
Consider the usual scalar product of the vectors $u=(-1, 2, 1)$ and $v=(3, -6, -3)$ of $\mathbb{R}^3$. 
Choose the right answer:
answer1: The vectors $u$ and $v$ are collinear and the magnitude of $u$ is $\sqrt{6}$.
answer2: The set $\{ u, v\}$ is orthogonal and the magnitude of $u$ is $\sqrt{6}$.
answer3: The vectors $u$ and $v$ are collinear and the magnitude of $u$ is $6$.
answer4: The set $\{ u, v\}$ is orthogonal and the magnitude of $u$ is $6$.

question: What are the possible types of data in statistics?
answer1: Numerical (quantitative), categorical (qualitative or nominal), and ordinal (ranked).

question:

$$\begin{cases}
3x & + & 2y & - & z & + & 2t & = & 1\\
x & - & y & + &2 z & - & 4t & = & -1\\

2x & + & 3y & - & 2z & + & t & = & 2
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has a unique solution.
answer3: The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter.

The figure displays an irrigation system for a small flowerbed. $A$, $B$ and $C$ are water sprinklers. Assume that, for water to get from $X$ to $Y$, it can go either through $A$ and $B$, or through $C$, or both ways. Water can only get through if the sprinklers are working, according to the following probabilities: $P(A)=95\%$, $P(B)=95\%$, $P(C)=90\%$. Calculate the probability of water not being able to get through from $X$ to $Y$.
Consider the equation $x^3+4x^2=10$. Consider the bisection method to solve the problem in the set $[1,2]$. What is the approximation after 3 iterations?

Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the values of the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
ax & + & y & = & 1 \\ 
bx & + & y & = & 2 \\ 
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
If $b=a$, the system has no solution. 

If $b\neq a$, the system has $\left(\frac{1}{b-a},\,\frac{b-2a}{b-a}\right)$ as its unique solution
answer2: The system has no solutions for every $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
The system has no solutions if $a,b\neq 1$. 

If $a=b=1$, the system has $\left(x,\,\frac{x}{2}\right)$ as solution for every $x\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4: For every $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$, the system has $\left(a-b+x,\,\frac{b-a+x}{2}\right)$ as its unique solution.

Consider the following linear programming problem to determine the optimum production schedule concerning three products $x_1$, $x_2$ and $x_3$ to maximize the profit regarding Company XLK Lda. The production of these products requires resources 1 and 2. 

\[\begin{array}{ll}	
\text{Maximize} & Z= 3x_{1}+x_{2}+5x_{3}\\
\text{subject to} & 6x_{1}+3x_{2}+5x_{3}\leq 45 \text{ (Resource 1)}\\
& 3x_{1}+4x_{2}+5x_{3}\leq 30 \text{ (Resource 2)}\\
& x_{i}\geq 0, i=1~to~3\\	
\end{array}
\]	

Let $S_1$ and $S_2$ be the slack variables for the respective constraints. After we apply the simplex method, the final incomplete simplex tableau is:

\[
\begin{array}{l|ccccc|c}
& x_{1} & x_{2} & x_{3} &  S_{1} & S_{2} & \\
\hline
x_{1} & 1 & -1/3  & 0 &  1/3 & -1/3 & 5 \\
x_{3} & 0 & 1  & 1 &  -1/5 & 2/5 & 3 \\
\hline
& &   & &   & & \\
\end{array}
\]	

If a new contraint $2x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}\leq 40 $ is included, determine the solution based on the final complete simplex tableau.

Find the solutions $\left(\text{in } \mathbb{R}^{2} \right)$ of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x &- &y &+ &z &+ &2t &= &2 \\
2x &+ &3y &+ &7z &+ &4t &= &-1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(1-2z-2t,\,-1-z,\,z,\,t\right)$ as solution for every $z,t\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1-2z,\,-1-z,\,z,\,0\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4: The system has $\left(1,-1,0,0\right)$ as its unique solution.

question:
Consider the differentiable function $f:\mathbb{R}^{2}\rightarrow \mathbb{R},$ $%
f(x,y)=e^{ax^{2}+by^{2}}$. It satisfies the equations:
answer1:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\left( x,y\right) =2axf(x,y),
\dfrac{\partial^{2}f}{\partial x^{2}}\left( x,y\right) =\left( 2a+4a^{2}x^{2}\right) f(x,y),%
\dfrac{\partial ^{2}f}{\partial x\partial y}(x,y)=4abxyf(x,y).$
answer2:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\left( x,y\right) =2af(x,y),\dfrac{\partial
^{2}f}{\partial x^{2}}\left( x,y\right) =\left( 2a+4a^{2}x^{2}\right) f(x,y),%
\dfrac{\partial ^{2}f}{\partial x\partial y}(x,y)=4abxyf(x,y).$
answer3:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\left( x,y\right) =2axf(x,y),\dfrac{\partial
^{2}f}{\partial x^{2}}\left( x,y\right) =\left( 2a+4a^{2}x\right) f(x,y),%
\dfrac{\partial ^{2}f}{\partial x\partial y}(x,y)=4abf(x,y).$
answer4:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\left( x,y\right) =2axf(x,y),\dfrac{\partial
^{2}f}{\partial x^{2}}\left( x,y\right) =\left( 2a+4a^{2}x^{2}\right) f(x,y),%
\dfrac{\partial ^{2}f}{\partial x\partial y}(x,y)=4bxyf(x,y).$

question: Consider the bases $B=\left\{(2,1,-1),(-3,2,0),(0,-1,3)\right\}$ and $B'=\left\{(-1,0,2),(0,-3,0),(0,1,1)\right\}$ for $\mathbb{R}^3$. The transition matrix from $B$ to $B'$ is:
Mark the vector which is not a linear combination of $u=(1,0,-3)$ and  $v=(0,-4,2)$.

Consider the function $f:\mathbb{R}^{2} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ given by

$$f(x,y):=\begin{cases}
xy\dfrac{x^2-y^2}{x^2+y^2} & \text{if } (x,y)=(0,0) \\
0 & \text{if } (x,y) = (0,0)
\end{cases}$$

Calculate the second order derivatives at $(0,0)$ and establish if they are equal.
answer1: $1 = \dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x \partial y}(0,0) \neq \dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y \partial x}(0,0) = -1$.
answer2: $\dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x \partial y}(0,0) = \dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y \partial x}(0,0) = -1$.
answer3: $\dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x \partial y}(0,0) = \dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y \partial x}(0,0) = 1$.
answer4: $\dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x \partial y}(0,0) = \dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y \partial x}(0,0)=0$.

question:
Find the solutions $\left(\text{in } \mathbb{C}^2\right)$ of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
z &- &iw &= &1 \\
iz &- &w &= &1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\bigg(\frac{1-i}{2},\frac{-1+i}{2}\bigg)$ as unique solution.
answer3: The system has $(z,-iz)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.
answer4: The system has $\bigg(\frac{1-i}{2},\frac{1+i}{2}\bigg)$ as unique solution.

The Childfair Company has three plants producing child push chairs that are to be shipped to four distribution centers. Plants $1$, $2$, and $3$ produce $12$, $17$, and $11$ shipments per month, respectively. Each distribution center needs to receive $10$ shipments per month. The distance (in miles) from each plant ($i$) to the respective distributing centers ($j$) is given below:

\[
\begin{array}{c|c|c|c|c}
\text{Plant Dist. Center} & \text{1} & \text{2} & \text{3}  & \text{4}  \\
\text{1} & 800  & 1300 &  400 & 700\\
\text{2} & 1100 & 1400 &  600 & 1000 \\
\text{3} & 600  & 1200 &  800 & 900\\
\end{array}
\]	

The freight cost for each shipment is $100.50?$ per mile. Use the transportation simplex method to determine how much should be shipped from each plant to each of the distribution centers each month, to minimize the total shipping cost. Use the minimum cost rule to obtain an initial basic feasible solution.

Find the solutions $\left(\text{in } \mathbb{C}^2\right)$ of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
(1+i)z& + & (1-i)w & = & i \\
(1-i)z& + & (1+i)w & = & 1-i
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The unique solution of the linear system is $\bigg(\frac{3+i}{4},-\frac{1+i}{4}\bigg)$.
answer2: The solutions of the linear system are of the form $\bigg(\frac{1+i}{4},\frac{-1+i}{4}+z\bigg)$, for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.
answer3: The linear system has no solutions.
answer4: The linear system has the vector $(i,-i)$ has its unique solution.

question: Maximize $f:\mathbb{R}^{3}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}$ given by $f(x_{1},x_{2},x_{3})=x_{1}x_{2}x_{3}$ under the restrictions $x_{1},x_{2},x_{3}\geq0$ and $2x_{1}+2x_{2}+4x_{3}\leq6$.

$$\begin{cases}
x & + & 2y & - & 3z & = & 4 \\
x & + & 3y & - & z & = & 11 \\
2x & + & 5y & - & 5z & = & 13 \\
x & + & 4y & + & z & = & 18
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The linear system has $\left(4,\,3,\,2\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer2: The linear system has $\left(4,\,2,\,3\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The linear system has no solutions.
answer4: The linear system has infinitely many solutions, which are of the form $\left(2z,\,z+1,\,z\right)$ for each $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
